content.user_title: Convert PRDs to JSON Tasks for Ralph-TUI
content.value_statement: Transform lengthy Product Requirements Documents into structured, executable JSON task files. Ralph-tui uses these files to autonomously implement features story by story with proper dependency management and quality gates.
actual_capabilities: Extract Quality Gates from PRD markdown files and append them to each user story
Parse user stories from PRD text and convert to structured JSON format
Set up dependencies between stories using the dependsOn array
Generate properly formatted prd.json files for ralph-tui consumption
Validate JSON structure against ralph-tui schema requirements
Derive branch names from feature descriptions in kebab-case format
limitations: Requires well-structured PRD input with clear user stories and acceptance criteria
Output is specific to ralph-tui format and may need adaptation for other tools
Does not validate that stories are appropriately sized for single iterations
Cannot automatically detect circular dependencies in complex project structures

use_cases.title: Development Team Task Planning
use_cases.description: Product managers convert PRDs into executable task files that ralph-tui can process autonomously, enabling AI agents to implement features story by story.

use_cases.title: Solo Developer Project Management
use_cases.description: Individual developers break down large features into manageable, dependency-ordered stories with clear acceptance criteria and quality gates.

use_cases.title: AI-Assisted Feature Implementation
use_cases.description: Teams use the generated prd.json files with ralph-tui to have Claude or other AI agents implement features automatically while maintaining quality standards.

prompt_templates.title: Convert Existing PRD
prompt_templates.prompt: Convert this PRD to prd.json format for ralph-tui. Extract the Quality Gates section and append those commands to each user story's acceptance criteria. Ensure proper dependency ordering with dependsOn arrays.
prompt_templates.scenario: You have an existing PRD markdown file that needs to be converted

prompt_templates.title: Create From Feature Description
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a prd.json file for this feature: [describe feature]. Include 3-5 user stories with proper dependencies (schema first, then backend, then UI). Add standard quality gates: typecheck, lint, and tests.
prompt_templates.scenario: Starting from a feature description rather than a full PRD

prompt_templates.title: Add Quality Gates to Existing JSON
prompt_templates.prompt: I have this prd.json file. Add these quality gates to every user story: `pnpm typecheck`, `pnpm lint`, and `pnpm test`. For UI stories, also add browser verification.
prompt_templates.scenario: Updating an existing prd.json with quality gates

prompt_templates.title: Validate and Fix PRD JSON
prompt_templates.prompt: Check this prd.json for common errors: wrapper objects, wrong field names, missing required fields. Fix any issues and ensure it follows the flat root structure with name and userStories at the top level.
prompt_templates.scenario: Debugging validation errors in an existing prd.json file

output_examples.input: PRD with Quality Gates section containing `pnpm typecheck` and `pnpm lint`, plus three user stories for a task priority feature
output_examples.output: A prd.json file with a flat root structure containing name, branchName, description, and a userStories array. Each story includes id, title, description, acceptanceCriteria (story-specific plus quality gates), priority, passes: false, notes: empty string, and dependsOn array with proper dependency chains.

output_examples.input: Request to create JSON tasks for a user authentication feature
output_examples.output: Structured output with sequential story IDs (US-001, US-002, etc.), dependency ordering where schema changes come first, backend logic second, and UI components last. Quality gates appended to every story's acceptance criteria array.

best_practices: Always extract Quality Gates from the PRD first and append them to every user story's acceptance criteria
Keep each story small enough to complete in one ralph-tui iteration; split large stories into smaller ones
Order stories by dependency: schema changes first, then backend logic, then UI components, then integration
anti_patterns: Do not wrap the output in a 'prd' object; keep name and userStories at the root level
Do not use 'tasks' instead of 'userStories' as the array name; the field must be userStories
Do not use 'status' field; use 'passes' with boolean values (false for incomplete, true for complete)

faq.question: What is ralph-tui and how does it use the prd.json file?
faq.answer: Ralph-tui is a tool that runs AI agents to implement software features autonomously. It reads the prd.json file, selects the highest-priority story with no blocking dependencies, and spawns an AI agent to implement it. Once complete, it marks the story as passed and continues to the next.

faq.question: Why must the JSON be flat with fields at the root level?
faq.answer: Ralph-tui expects a specific schema where 'name' and 'userStories' are top-level fields. Wrapping them in a 'prd' object or using different field names will cause validation errors when ralph-tui tries to load the file.

faq.question: How do I determine the right size for a user story?
faq.answer: Each story should be completable in one ralph-tui iteration (roughly one AI context window). A good rule of thumb is that if you cannot describe the change in 2-3 sentences, it is too big. Examples of right-sized stories: add a database column with migration, add a UI component to an existing page, or update a server action with new logic.

faq.question: What should I do if my PRD does not have a Quality Gates section?
faq.answer: Ask the user what commands should pass for each story, or use sensible defaults like `npm run typecheck` and `npm run lint`. Quality gates ensure that every story meets minimum quality standards before being marked complete.

faq.question: How do dependencies work in the dependsOn array?
faq.answer: The dependsOn array contains story IDs that must be completed before the current story can be worked on. Ralph-tui will show dependent stories as blocked until their prerequisites are marked as passed. This ensures proper implementation order, such as creating database schemas before UI components that use them.

faq.question: Can I use this skill with tools other than ralph-tui?
faq.answer: While the output format is specifically designed for ralph-tui, the structured JSON can be adapted for other tools. However, the field names and flat structure are optimized for ralph-tui's requirements and may need modification for other systems.
